extracted_information: This module focuses on using assistive technology (AT) for accessibility testing, particularly screen readers, to identify and fix code issues that interfere with website or app usage for people with disabilities. It emphasizes that testing aims to detect problems, not fully emulate the user experience.

features.title: Screen Reader Testing Basics
features.description: Screen readers convert website/app code into speech or Braille output. They are essential for blind/deafblind individuals and can benefit those with low vision, reading disorders, and cognitive disabilities. Testing should involve multiple types of ATs.

VoiceOver_iOS.Explore: Drag one finger around the screen
VoiceOver_iOS.Move_up_or_down: Swipe up or down with three fingers
VoiceOver_iOS.Change_pages: Swipe left or right with three fingers
VoiceOver_iOS.Next/previous: Swipe left or right with one finger

features.title: Assistive Technology Testing Best Practices
details: Familiarize with screen reader documentation and essential commands.
Goal of testing is to detect code problems interfering with usage, not to emulate a screen reader user's full experience.
Engage with AT users/organizations to gain insight into their experience.
No single 'best' screen reader for testing; choice depends on OS, browser, and user analytics.

Screen readers work best when used with calibrated OS and web browser combinations (e.g., JAWS on Windows with Chrome/Firefox/Edge, NVDA on Windows with Chrome/Firefox, VoiceOver on macOS with Safari).
Incorporate accessibility design throughout the development process.
Integrate AT testing with other pre-launch testing.

details.fix: Update HTML to use semantic elements like proper heading levels and landmarks; ensure visual presentation doesn't obscure programmatic structure.

details.issue: Link context (unclear link purpose or redirection)
details.fix: Add more information using ARIA labels (e.g., `aria-label='Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) opens in a new window'`) or additional visual text to clarify link purpose and destination.

details.issue: Decorative images announced by screen reader
details.fix: Hide decorative images from screen readers by adding `role='presentation'` or `role='none'` to the image element (e.g., `<svg role='presentation'>`). Avoid `aria-hidden='true'` as it can hide all content within the element.
Hide CSS-generated decorative elements like bullets from screen readers using `role='presentation'` or `role='none'` on the relevant HTML element.

details.issue: Form fields missing visual and programmatic labels
details.fix: Replace placeholders with visually persistent and programmatically connected `<label>` elements. Ensure labels remain visible.
